Review title: Heart of Darkness on the streets of LA
Review_body: I like the movie. I live in LA and saw up close neighborhoods I wouldn't venture into with a panzered Humbvie. But I learned that gangs have a code of honor. The story of a rookie cop Jake (Ethan Hawke) getting his street IQ bumped up a few notches by veteran Narc Alonzo (Denzyl Washington). But is Alonzo the truth the way and the light or a seductive demon? There's enough seduction and mystery to keep us interested. There is a boatload of really good acting between the two leads as they drive around the streets of LA fulfilling Alonzos agenda. Unfortunately the movie has two really week moments for which I suspect director Antoine Fuqua is still taking heat. Both moments are heroic unbelievable revivals of Jake. I suggest Antoine should have made an alternate ending without such a heroic revival and stuck that on the DVD for the viewers who were taken out of their theatre seats and put on the streets of LA. 4 stars.

Although the subject matter in Training Day may be unfavorable to acknowledge, the movie is still significant because of the quality of work throughout this film. One of the most authentic depictions of the streets in recent memory. The gangsters in this movie act like they came right off the corner. I think it is important that people realize that this movie is not at all far fetched when you consider the Rampart scandal and the story of "corrupt cop", Rafael Perez and the "boy scout" detective that eventually blew the whistle on this corrupted department. Rap fans would be interested to know that this same Rafael Perez and one of his colleagues David Mack have been linked to Death Row CEO Suge Knight and many loosely suspect they had some hand in the rocky events that eventually led to Tupac and Biggie's deaths. Great performances by Denzel and Ethan. To me this movie is hard to look at for some people because the injustice it shows never affected them and in a sense they either feel guilty for it in a way or they just despise the whole environment but whether you chose to accept it or not you can't hide from this movie because the subject matter is relevant and the movie's quality is exceptional.

I had never heard of the movie Training Day, until after I saw A Beautiful Mind. Then I had only heard of it because I could not believe how Russell Crowe could have lost the Oscar for best actor. So I researched some critic reviews on Training Day, got my snacks, rented the movie, and sat down to try to figure out why Mr. Washington beat Mr. Crowe.Boy it did not take me long. The very first scene in which Denzel Washington's Alonzo appears, grabbed my attention and made me stand back and say "Okay, I think I'm going to like this performance". However, not only was I absolutely blown away by Mr. Washington's potrayl of a cooked cop, but I found the movie to be extremely enjoyable. Ethan Hawke was a perfect contrast to Washington, and the director and writer did a great job of capturing the feel of such a neighborhood.It's still hard for me to say that Russell Crowe did not deserve to win, however after seeing this movie and knowing what a great actor Mr. Washington is, I can honestly say that I have no complaint with his victory. It was a tough decision to make between the two, but in the end I am glad Mr. Washington got his Oscar.

Review title: A Movie 'MADE' for an actor like Denzel
Review_body: I love movies like this and Im sure Denzel Washingtons enjoyment of acting in this movie greatly assisted him in achieving the Oscar for best actor. The movie is intense and I can't pass on a picture about a corrupt police officer and who better than Denzel. I was gripped to the screen the entire time. He has always done a great performance with movies involving gangsters and the ghettos, the violent sides of society. His being a police officer added a bunch to the movie and really increased the interest. He is actually a gangster at heart yet is a cop so feels he has power over people and may do whatever he wishes.

This movie was outstanding. Denzel stole the show and definately deserved the Oscar. He was brilliant in this movie. He had me sucked into his role almost to the point I forgot I was watching an actor play a part. He WAS the part. The movie did a good job of making you argue both sides (or philosophies of police work). It was difficult to sway one way or the other (at least 'til the last 1/2 hour). Good movie, great performance by the cast.

This is one of the best action movies ever. I warmly recommend it to anyone. Honestly, this movie deserves a much better rating. I don't get it how such a movie can get a 1?!?. To give 1 to a movie it means you didn't find anything good in it. Really, there is nothing which is good in this movie? The acting, the costumes, the haircuts, the soundtrack, the storyline ,..., none of this? The problem with this ratings on IMDb is that anyone can vote. Almost all the movies have one star ratings and also ten star ratings. I don't get why some people, only vote to give a bad rating to movie which is good. If you don't like a certain genre of movies you shouldn't watch them. Some time ago I only liked comedies and I didn't bother watching other type of movies, but since I grow up I understood that every movie genre has at least a one good movie. There are good dramas, horrors, comedies, action movies, science fiction movies and so on. So when I rate a movie, I don't let the genre of the movie affect my judgement. For example I'm not really interested in science fiction movies, but there are SF movies which I rated with ten stars because they deserved it. So, in my opinion people shouldn't let the bias affect their judgement when they rate a movie. Training day is a great movie and nothing will change this fact. Also, Denzel Washington is a great actor and the fact he won an Oscar for his performance proves my point.

SPOILERS FOLLOW !!!What a terribly disappointing, dark, moody, dismal and drawn-out flick. Not "enjoyable" from any point of view other than Washington's always-fine acting.May be OK to watch if you're doing something else while watching the screen !Ethan Hawke's acting was stilted, amateurish. Denzel Washington at his usual high standard.

I hate to break the news to you guys but cops like Alonzo ARE OUT THERE and need to be acknowledged. Acting like the problem doesn't exist does not solve it. You don't have to go that deep to know that Alonzo was once a good cop who just got fed up w/ 'police procedures.' If you acknowledge that Jake's shallow-mindedness at the beginning of the film only allows him to look at the perks of making detective and how the progress of the day transforms him, you can really appreciate Ethan's portrayal of him. Let's face it, a bad day at the office when you're a narcotics detective differs greatly from that of an office executive and the different stresses can warrant different results.Even the street rhetoric was authentic. Maybe you guys need to get out of the 'burbs more. You guys didn't actually expect eloquent dialogue with little or no profanity, did you? The only part of this movie I struggle with is Dr. Dre's terrible overacting and that isn't nearly enough to take away from the overall result.

Review title: Very capturing and extremely well performed
Review_body: I only saw the film yesterday on video! I thought it absolutely very exciting from beginning to end, with great things in it to reflect on, concerning moral/standards. And just a scaring picture of one of the ways that the world works too. As others have mentioned, the scene where Harris is exposed as what he really is, is absolutely spectacular. No wonder D.W. got an Oscar for this performance.This is highly due to the brilliant performances from both main actors, but not least Denzel W. who made my blood run cold with his outstanding performance.I highly recommend this movie.

Review title: Performance of a Lifetime from Denzel!
Review_body: Wow! What a superb film, Denzel Washington at his superb best. Denzel plays a terrific part as Alonzo Harris, a cop with a dark personality.From the moment you set eyes on him you can relies that Alonzo is a feisty character, who will stop at nothing to get what he wants.Ethan Hawke provides excellent backup but Denzel steals the show. Training Day is an exciting, fast paced, action cop thriller that will keep you on the edge of your seat from the outset and throughout. It's not perfect, however it is interesting, exciting and most of all entertaining from start to finish and I would urge anyone to take the time to watch it.

"For of all sad words of tongue or pen, The saddest are these: "It might have been!" - John Greenleaf WhittierThis is indeed fitting for Training day. When the film got underway, I found myself enthralled by the characters. The screenplay seemed to be set at just the right pace, and I was quite enjoying myself.Just when it was starting to get really good-BANG! Voila, we have ourselves John-Woo-esquire action sequences, ending all semblance of plausibility.The performances were great. Denzel Washington was terrific, of course, but the standout for me was Ethan Hawke's honest performance as the idealistic rookie.I'd say its worth a watch, just don't harbor any great expectations.

In all honesty, I have to admit that I went in to see Training Day at the Toronto Film Festival with somewhat less than stellar expectations. When I walked out I was impressed with what turned out to be a well written, well directed and incredibly well acted L.A. cop thriller. The story focuses on Ethan Hawke's character, a lowly cop being promoted to a narc who goes out on a day of training with an unconventional undercover veteran played by Denzel Washington. I won't say too much more about the plot but I must say that both actors play their roles very well; Hawke is very subdued while Washington is completely over the top. The movie moves at a satisfyingly quick pace and keeps you hooked right until the very end. The film does have its flaws but for a film of its genre they are so few and far between that you barely notice them. If you're looking for a fun way to spend two hours without having to think too hard then go out and see Training Day.

There is only one reason why this flick will never have its rightful place in Hollywood history. With great anticipation, I watched Denzel Washington (who I believe walks on water) take on his first roll as a bad guy. Even though his performance was stellar, there was just something significantly wrong with this film throughout. While contemplating the thin line between art imitating life and its opposite, consider the following.A Hollywood good guy who takes on the role of a bad guy is best served by pairing with someone who is also reputed as good. Remember the movie "Heat"? Ethan Hawke is not that guy.While the movie was set in the most notorious urban jungle, the good cop managed to do some things that simply can't be done by a white cop in a real environment of the same notoriety. Even people from the squeaky clean suburbs know that downtrodden minorities have no love (or trust) for white police officers simply because they are white (the oppressor). I could go on criticizing Training Day for other little quirks, but it really would not matter. There truly is only one reason why this potentially great movie (great like Gladiator) won't ever be regarded as such. Somebody made a fatal casting mistake. If Cuba Gooding Jr. had been the rookie, you can bet that this movie would have been in line for several Oscar awards. As fate would have it instead, Denzel Washington's first performance as a bad guy may go down in history as a forgettable moment. Imagine a sequel to this movie starring Ethan Hawke now as a veteran. Would you go see it? What a shame... Denzel did such an awesome job!

I'm not even going to waste any more time on this film...3/10.

Training Day is a dynamic film about the darkest and most intense side of police work.  The moral dilemnas and predicaments that arise for the aspiring narcotics officer are real problems that officers must face at times.  The movie portrays how some officers find themselves in the "underworld" environment, without ever planning to enter it.The scene in the car, after they do the felony stop on the teenagers, shows how a seemingly strong-minded cop might be manipulated and it all starts there.I was also impressed by the realism as far as police work.  The way the suspects refuse to cooperate, the artificial respect of the dealers with the cops, the drug sell hunting, the drug swallowing, the language, etc.If you're a law enforcement officer, especially a patrol cop, this is a REQUIRED viewing.Let's remember that as extreme as the film might seem, most of it happens regularly in the big cities.  Enjoy.

Training Day is a bold and amazing experience. This film goes beyond painting the picture of a bad day as an undercover cop; it draws you into a world that is both frightening and intriguing. Denzel is perfectly cast. He does not just make this role better, he makes it possible. The fact that most of us can not conceive of disliking Denzel Washington is precisely what makes Alonzo Harris ( his character ) compelling. The evil of this crooked "wolf" is so plausibly wrapped in charm and humanity, that the decision to dislike him is painful. Denzel causes us to empathize with Hoyt's ( Ethan Hawke's ) gut wrenching dilemma - the audience is forced into the same, brutal indecision. Hawke skillfully plays his part, and is totally believable. I could identify with his character in every hesitation, and each surrender. All in all, a brilliant film. Not for the faint of heart, but not to be missed.

Let me start out with this: This movie is amazing. End of story. I've read through the other reviews here, with people nitpicking the movie and finding minuscule "plot-holes" that are too stupid to be repeated here, and let me just say: WHO CARES?!?! Training Day is a great movie, and here's why: Denzel Washington. This film is the Greatest Actor in the World's shining achievement, and that alone makes it great. The character of Alonzo is one of the most menacing villains to hit the screen, and it's all because of Denzel. He BECAME Alonzo - almost everything that Denzel says in this movie is purely his creation (and I know - I've read the script.) For those of you who said Denzel was not Oscar-worthy in this film - you are extremely wrong. Just sit down and watch all the clever things he says (that he made up), all the subtle nuances. The scene in the car after they kill Roger is one of my favorite scenes of all time, because he goes from ghetto and evil to sweet and almost fatherly. The shift is brilliant, and Denzel pulls it off completely.Like I said above, picking out irrelevant "plot-holes" is pointless...every single plot-hole that was brought up in other reviews has a logical explanation, but people are so against this movie that they feel they need to find some need to tear it apart, and since they can't tear apart Denzel's amazing performance, they focus on minuscule plot elements. This movie is GREAT. It's a gripping tour into a side of the streets we aren't exposed to, and Alonzo is our guide. And try and tell me it isn't classic cinema when Alonzo, broken and beaten at the end, puts a cigarette into his mouth and says "I'm still winnin'...I can't lose..." Denzel's greatest performance, and if you know anything about his acting skills, that is SAYING something. Please don't turn away from this movie. It's worth your time, believe me.

Review title: Why do I always favour the bad guy in good & bad cop flicks?
Review_body: I rated this film 7 out of 10. I enjoyed watching it, but it isn't so great as to stick out above the rest of the films in the genre. Personally I often favour the bad guy in good vs evil flicks, and this one's no difference. Alonzo (Denzel Washington)is a real badass slick-talking-smooth-walking copper. He's got "bad cop" written all over him and his wrong car and clothes I liked it. And of course his counterpart Jake Hoyt(Ethan Hawk) is the obligatory goody-two-shoes rookie on his first (and only, as far Alonzo is concerned) Training Day on the job as a narc. [SOME (a wee bit) SPOILING AHEAD, SO WANNA-WATCH-AS-A-VIRGIN TYPES STOP HERE] Believe you me, Alonzo really proves to be a bad number, and of course he tries to drag Hoyt along and prevent a way back to good coppers land. And of course this will not stick in the end. I would like a film on this subject where the bad cop is less obvious and the good cop is a badass himself too. I hate the goody 2 shoes types like Hoyt, it's so, emm well, obvious and thus boring. Enough complaints, it's a good flick, lots of badass action, junkies dealers pimps and ho's, and some no go neighborhood shots! Enough pace to keep you at the edge of your seat for the 2 hours it lasts, a great killing scene and mis-en-scene and a satisfactory getting-rid-of-the-bad-character scene. 'nough said, go watch it an U be the judge! Denzel gets a 9 out of 10, Hawke 6/10. Notice Dr Dre and Snoop Doggy Dog as Paul & Blue (if you dig these fellas)!

Review title: Great performances in an average, formula blaxploitation film
Review_body:
In 20 years we will look back at this in the same way we look back at movies like Cleopatra Jones, Friday Foster, Foxy Brown, etc... and will take it for what it is: a cheap portrayal of minorities with the basic message that "those drug sellin', gun carryin' blacks and latinos are just gonna kill each other," except for the occasional hero who really wants to "change the way things are." Formula, formula, formula!  (At least in most blaxploitation movies, the hero gets to be black!)Fantastic performances and a high budget help it to stand above other films in the genre. Now, I really enjoy Pam Grier movies, Dolemite, Cleopatra Jones, Shaft, and so on.  I can watch those and have a great time. I also enjoyed Training Day, but let's be real about what kind of film this is.  At its core, it is blaxploitation.
*** POSSIBLE SPOILERS AHEAD ***Stock characters fill the script: a lone hero who is pure of heart and wants to clean things up, a collection of bad guys with one really bad guy who leads them that's in it for the money, and ultimately "whitey" is in control (the nice, older white gentlemen Alonzo meets in the club.) Unimaginative dialog is  characteristic of the genre and that detail wasn't overlooked here. (How many times can you say "dawg" and "ni**er" without it being repetitive?)Worth seeing for an entertaining time, but not high art.

Training Day is a gritty character-based crime drama.  It focuses on a rookie cop, Jake Hoyt (Ethan Hawke) hoping to make a strong impression on the leader of a group of LAPD undercover narcotics officers, Alonzo Harris (Denzel Washington).  As Hoyt's training day unfolds he is faced with moral dilemmas with what he was taught in his past training and what Alonzo says and does.  Alonzo's policing methods toe the line between "good detective work" and "illegal."The interaction between these two characters is really the heart of the movie, and Washington and Hawke play their roles brilliantly.  Washington definitely deserves his Oscar for this performance, as he constructs Alonzo as a very over-the-top cocky veteran who believes that his way is the only way of doing things.  Hawke's character is a perfect foil to this, as he's subdued and uneasy as he faces tough choices but also hopes to make a strong impression on Alonzo to advance his career.The plot develops very nicely, and I recommend watching the movie twice because the second time around, there are small details that you notice which all tie in to the "chess game" that develops in the film.  Also watch the DVD for insightful directors commentary from Antoine Fuqua.  It provides interesting background on the acting of Hawke and Washington and the realism of the undercover cop and gangbanger characters.  Strong acting by musicians Dr Dre, Snoop Dogg, and Macy Gray in their limited roles.  Each created memorable characters.To sum it up, great acting, great directing, and a great movie.  It's a shame I missed it on the big screen.

I was extremely satisfied with Mr. Washington's performance in this movie. He made me believe he was a crooked narcotics officer with no regard for anyone but himself, yet I was mysteriously attracted to him and repelled to him at the same time!The psychological and physical games orchestrated and performed by Detective Alonzo Harris (Washington) on just about every character in the story were both believable and brilliant.The story does teach a lesson, "What goes around, comes around!"  I recommend this movie to any and everyone.

Review title: Until when can you tolerate the bad society without to really became part of?
Review_body: The difference between good and bad is just an illusion? Until when can you tolerate the bad society without to really became part of?13 years is too long time!Undercover cop Alonzo Harris(Denzel Washington)after the 13 years spent together with criminals,drug dealers and offenders became a criminal too. The corrupt cops like Harris appeared with the cop movies but earlyer in secondary roles.Afther the movies like Copland and L.A.Confidential we know that corrupt cops does exist.After 24 hours together with his superior Alonzo Harris,the rookie Jake Hoyt(Ethan Hawke) will be convinced about this thing.Jake has one day to prove that he is a 'good' cop but he will be pulled deeper and deeper in Alonzo's world,and his life will be changed forever.At the begining he don't knows that his life is in danger,but in the next hours he will run for his life.Housband and father,man of justice,he don't understands Alonzo's actions,he can't cheat,steal or perpetrate a crime.Thinking about his job and his family he respects the orders but when he finds himself responsable of a crime comited by Alonzo takes gun in his hand and starts hunting his superior.Hawke's acting is very good but is a 'shadow' behind Washington's character.Cruel and arrogant,he is Mr.Cool(like John Travolta in 'Swordfish').Denzel Washington is a great actor,this movie is one of his bests. He usually don't plays negative roles but he is the ideal actor for Alonzo. This suspenseful actiondrama is of the 2001's bests,the story reflects the truth,the play of the actors is great and the soundtrack can't be missed. It is recommended for every Denzel Washington fan!Rating:9/10

Review title: an Oscar?, what were they thinking ?
Review_body: I think that I have spent too long watching this film so I do not intend to make this take up more than 3 minutes: I like the director, I love the lead actors, I love the genre, and I have been advised by many to watch this accordingly. But This film was incredibly dull, offensive in its blandness, and predictable and more than anything else what surprised me it has absolutely no intelligence on any level at all. Gee when I think what we got from for example 'the inside man'. Now there was a film: smart, slick, engaging, unpredictable, characters I could believe, and the feel of New York. This movie at most may offer a slice of the dark side of corruption in LA told by a relatively convincing palette of actors but there were far too many problems here that sank this movie for me: Denzel Washington was too self-conscious in many places, Ethan Hawke was oddly more convincing than Washington all around. This emphasis on ''nothing is as it seems'' was played out for me by the first 40 minutes when there just seemed to be no plot other than here is a typical ''non typical'' training day: whatever!!! It was insulting! Surely this film cannot grab anybody with any imagination. I'd prefer to watch sly Stallone or Steven Seagal any day if I wanted mindless dross like this, at least those alternatives can be funny or amusing on a certain level. My time is up, or rather its time is up, and I wasted too much time tonight on this already. Happy to kiss this one off guys (btw I rarely make a negative review but I had to let this one out despite the Oscar for Washington), what were they thinking!!! :)Good luck!

Director Antoine Fuqua did Training Day justice in this crime drama. The story starts as a rookie narcotics officer Jake Hoyt (Ethan Hawke) first day with a corrupt veteran detective Alonzo Harris (Denzel Washington). Jake is stunned by the methods that Det. Alonzo uses in his daily routine. Because Jake wants to become narcotics office he follows Alonzo instructions. As the story unfolds it is found out that Alonzo is in debt with the Russian mob and they have a deadline on when he must pay them back or he will be killed. This causes Jake to be thrust into Alonzo world of using drugs, stealing, and even killing. This film is centered on the theme good versus evil. Jake is the naive rookie narcotics officer trying to bring down the overbearing corrupt veteran detective Alonzo Harris. The cinematography was great in showing this. The camera angles and lighting were great for the fact that it showed the desperate measure that Alonzo was willing to through in order to pay back the money and save his life. A few scenes stood out as very powerful scenes in the movie. In the beginning of the movie Alonzo with a gun forced Jake to smoke PCP. Little did Jake know that this was part of a big plan Alonzo created to get out of debt. The use of slow motion was awesome as Jake smoked the PCP. There was also the use of different colors in the lighting. It showed how zoned out Jake was. Another scene in Training Day was where Alonzo was cornered by the Russian mob there was misty fog. The lighting was very dim and then the gun shots rang out. Hundreds of bullets were let off. This was a very powerful scene in the movie.This is a great must see movie. Highly recommended.

Parents beware: the level of bad language used leaves nothing to the imagination! On a side note: YOU GET TO SEE EVA MENDES COMPLETELY NAKED!!!! Lol, that certainly wasn't something I was expecting as i was watching, but a glimpse of her body at the end definitely was worth the wait!

There is one quick line in this feature that is pivotal to the plot: when Alonzo takes Jake to see Roger, the dealer, Roger asks Alonzo about the Russians. Roger says, " . . . you know I've got your back." So, think about the irony: Roger was promising Alonzo protection from the Russians; if Alonzo had not killed Roger, he would have been safe! This, I believe, is the supreme irony of Alonzo's reckless campaign to save his life by killing the one man who was prepared to save him. The hubris that Alonzo demonstrated is a symptom of his arrogant self-reliance - he planned everything in order to get his money, with no thought for the lives of those whom he used to achieve it. And this ties back to the joke Roger told Jake about the snail: Alonzo is like the snail in that he thought he could go anywhere or do anything without being stopped!

Interesting movie this , Alonzo as the good/bad cop out to get the big bad guys but corrupt at the same time , the rookie at first merely out to get bad guys , then Alonzo due to his going bad. Then we had the Hispanic/Black street gang members primarily portrayed as bad guys but then assisting rookie to get to Alonzo , so were they then doing good ? Not a traditional American cop movie , as there was no clear distinction between bad guys and good guys and as there usually is a very clear one I thought Training Day was quite radical for the USA , as it portrayed a mix of bad/good guys doing bad and good , so who was the good guy ?

Review title: A magnificent depiction of a shady world
Review_body: The magic of the movies is that they allow us to see worlds and experience emotions that are sometimes distant from our own and our immediate environment. Antoine Fuqua in Training day brings to us a world of gangs, drugs and corruption that is alien to must of us, but which nevertheless exists, sometimes transcending its own borders and coming to us in the form of news (The rampart scandal) and no matter if we close our eyes and ignore it, it will not go away. In that world we have two police officers, officer Hoyt, a rookie just assigned to an elite anti narcotics unit, and officer Alonzo, a veteran of the force, commanding the unit. Each one of those officers has his own set of values and morality, but no one is completely good or completely evil as absolute evil or absolute good are inexistent (in humans at least), ultimately they just want to take care of their own problems. Hoyt wants to take care of his family, his young wife, his new born child, he wants to escalate positions (don't we all) in the force and this new assignment may be the perfect place to start and he will do anything to nail it. Officer Alonzo has a more complicated set of problems, he has to get a million dollars and he has to do it today; otherwise he will be killed by the Russian mafia, but he has a plan and the plan involves Hoyt (a virgin shooter above suspicion) and Roger (a drug dealer with a lot of money in his kitchen floor). Basically the movie unfolds as Alonzo's plan goes into motion showing us glimpses of a corrupt and disturbing world, a world with its own rules and twisted morality, Smiley forgiving Hoyt's life as a return for having protected his cousin's honor, gang members shooting indiscriminately to protect the sandman's property, Stan and his friends giving Alonzo carte blanch to basically kill Roger and steal his money so he can save himself, etc. Denzel Washington work was impeccable; a well deserved Oscar, showing us a man who has moved the line a little bit each time to the point that he doesn't know where he is now, a man who has moved to the edge in a desperate attempt to save his life. Is he really that bad? After all he is a father, a husband, a friend appreciated by his team (if you think you can get away with it, we are with you) and colleagues. Maybe we just caught him in a bad day...a training day. If we want to make a better society for every one, we have to know what are the obstacles we have to overcome, training day show us some of those obstacles and then some.

Review title: Intensity from Denzel that we haven't seen in a while.
Review_body: Intensity from Denzel that we haven't seen in a while, he doesn't play this character so much as force the air into his lungs.  Even the usually disaffected, flaccid Ethan Hawke shows signs of life. But why couldn't we see more Eva Mendes?

They say that a good book cannot be put down, likewise a good film can be watched over and over, which is what I love about this film, it literally can be watched an unlimited number of times. A huge debt to his name, with no choice but to come up with the money or his soul in payment.Unfortunately for him, the new guy on his "Training Day" abruptly puts a stop to his plans.It's amazing how much can take place in one day, but if you love action, deceit and violence then you will love this film. In years to come, this film will be considered a classic, and if not one of the best movies of all time.

Training Day is one of the few movies these days that stand out. Denzel Washington acted very well, doing his job by making his character difficult by the viewer whether he is just a good cop bending the rules, or a crazy cop that should be locked up. Ethan Hawke also did a great job playing a character that is a kind-hearted person who knows right from wrong. This is a dark movie that will leave you guessing, and will leave you on the edge of your seat. This isn't a fantasy movie that seems too unrealistic, but a true to life movie that is as real as it can get. Plus, you get to see some fine acting by snoop dogg and others. This movie is a must-see, and Washington earned that academy award.

The movie is about the first day of Jake Hoyt (Ethan Hawke), a young soon to be narcotics officer, at work. It is actually a journey into the real world of the streets of LA as it is presented by prestigious detective Alonzo Harris (Denzel Washington). Hoyt soon realizes that Alonzo's methods are far from legal. All through his training day, he finds himself having to choose between his ethic and what Alonzo tells him what he should do, because the real world is a "jungle", and one has to be a "wolf" to survive in it. So, according to Alonzo, an officer could co-operate with drug dealers, steal money and even murder as long as he succeeds in his primary mission. Hoyt never seems to agree with this and when he finds out that the training is in fact a setup, he has to come after Alonzo. In the end Alonzo dies as a wolf because in this kind of game there is always a greater wolf.This was a really interesting movie. It shows a completely different aspect than the ideal world of police in the US as it appears in many other movies or TV shows. There is also an excellent performance by Denzel Washington. He surely deserved his Oscar award for that one.

from the moment i heard that trailer the film had sold me with its suaveness, the Denzel factor, and the fact Ethan hawke got to play another supporting role with such sheer acting brilliance. The action is spectacular matched only by the intrigue and suspense as Hawke finally unravels Washingtons plan for him. Hawke could be seen as the ultimate in anti-stereo typical cops, white and legit. the political factors in this film cannot be missed however the film is well shot, well written and well acted apart from Scott Glenn's terrible turn as Roger. the film is a symbol of denzel Washington's rise to the top and the line "king Kong ain't got nuthin on me" serves as an ego boast for Alonzo and Washington. Training Day Lacks the real magic however to make it a long time stayer in peoples minds but never the less a good watch.

I think I make a more convincing gangster wanna-be (and I am white and short).Still trying to figure out what the "movie critics" see in this one -- it definitely is not the portrayal of a human (or any other dilemma), coming of age, or dealing with one's personal demons.If you ever have an opportunity to watch this movie when you have time to kill and it doesn't cost you anything -- I guess you should go for it -- maybe you'll see something I did not.

It is one of Denzel's better movies in my own opinion, but I'm not a huge fan of his anyway. Due note that the first part is probably exactly what a cop would say. I really am not a cop.

I remember being lent this on DVD during the summer holidays by a mate soon after it was out. I must have watched it every day/second day for about a month! I loved it so much I could never get enough. Denzel and Ethan are a perfect match for this movie; I can't imagine anyone else playing their rolls. Can you? You will either love this movie or find it just a way to 'pass a night'. If you connect with it then you'll never forget it. I know I haven't and I haven't watched it since 2002 because I can remember every part in detail! Training Day is one of those movies which breaks new ground in terms of how a movie can come across to people. It was filmed in such locations such as Imperial Courts neighborhood which, until now, hasn't been filmed. The talk is the talk... you get a real sense of what it's like for these guys as narcotic officers and for what it's like for these guys as the 'bad guys' themselves. At the end of they day they're "Just people and they always were" (Ethan Hawk in a making of Traning day interview).The movie isn't the fastest paced one around - there are some slow moments but they are played out meaningfully due to some great acting talent which gels the scenes together well. The more you watch it, the more subtle lines and actions you will pick up which make this movie authentic.Overall, to each his own. I have found this to be one of my favorite movies due to great acting, great directing, great casting (Hawk, Washington, Scott Glen etc) and an interesting storyline.

Awesome, one of the best films ever and Denzel Washington does a very convincing portrayal of the cop who crosses the line, but you have to agree with some of his motives. I love when he shoots Roger and Jake freaks out, he makes a very good point when Jake asks why he shot a friend. "Why was he my friend, because he knew my first name? Roger sold crack to kids and the world is a better place with him dead!" Every point he makes about modern day "street" justice rings very true to modern day crime and justice. It sets the tone very well for an awesome films and all though he is ultimately the bad guy, Alonzo Harris is one of the best characters to every grace the big screen and you can't help but like the guy. There are some great cameos from Dr. Dre and Snoop DoggA true modern day classic. Highly recommended

Review title: One of the best cop movies ever made.
Review_body: I'm confused by the low ratings...this film is perfect if you're looking for a good, superbly acted cop film. Denzel Washington and Ethan Hawke are amazing in this film. And with a stellar supporting cast, this film gets better and better every time I watch it.

Without a doubt, Denzel Washington's performance in this movies is outstanding. Nevertheless, a lot of people criticize the plot while underlining that ''Training Day'' is not too great a movie to deserve any other acknowledgment. From my point of view, those statements are false because especially Washington's and Hawke's performances make this movie worth watching, plus, the plot much more interesting. Additionally, director Fuqua did a superb job, which is characterized by a magnificent authenticity in the presentation of Los Angeles' suburban areas. Again, I recommend this movie heavily, if you love gangster movies, then you cannot afford to miss this one. Generally, Alonzo Harris' quotes are legendary: ''To protect the sheep you gotta catch the wolf, and it takes a wolf to catch a wolf.'' - ''This s***'s chess, it ain't checkers''.
